summary: Appeal by leave of this Court is preferred against judgment and order dated 8th of February 2000 made by the Gauhati High Court in Writ No. 519 of 1997 confirming an order of the Gauhati High Court in Civil Rule No.1485 of 1992 dated 19th July 1997. The case of the workmen before the Labour Court is that on the night of 12th and 13th October 1980 the workmen concerned along with others came to the Estate, armed with deadly weapons and confined the Manager and others from 8.30 PM to 3.00 AM next morning and it is only after the manager gave it in writing under threat as assurance that 20% bonus would be paid, the gherao was lifted. The Appeal Court of the Gauhati High Court has held that the Labour Court could not have gone beyond the charge of superannuating the workmen when it held that they had extorted documents from the Manager of the Krishnakali Tea Estate.

summary: The Calcutta High Court has held that "Authorities have no jurisdiction to impose ban on such a dance." Tandava dance was not an essential religious rite of Ananda Margis, the Calcutta High Court has ruled. summary: Appeal No.: 5385 of 1998 and SLTIL APPEAL No. 5389-90 of 2002 Section 104(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure has been held to be general in nature by the Constitution Bench of the Allahabad High Court in Gulab Bai (supra) and, therefore, the right of appeal under Clause 15 of the Letters Patent of the Madras High Court would be available to a suitor irrespective of the provisions contained in sub-section (2) of Section 104 of the Code of Civil Procedure. It was urged that while enacting Section 100-A of the Code of Civil Procedure, it was not necessary for it to expressly mention that such appeal would not be maintainable irrespective of the fact that the same is provided for under the Letters Patent of different High Courts.

summary: A writ petition has been filed in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh challenging the decision of the Returning Officer to reject the nomination of the first respondent as an independent candidate in the 2004 general election. The High Court of Andhra Pradesh in its interim order of 2 May, 2004 directed the Returning Officer to allot the symbol of car which is reserved for the official candidate of the said political party only. Learned counsel submitted that the High Court was correct in holding that the Returning Officer had erred in allotting the reserved symbol of a car to the appellant on the ground that he was not a candidate set up by the Telengana Rashtra Samithi party.
